hello this is chef john from food wishes

to unemployed man's pudding or poor
man's plating as some people translate

it which by the way is a little

Depression hence the name and many of

our french-canadian friends thought it
would be the perfect thing to follow up

our poutine video with and I agreed so
with that let's go ahead get started

with the first of two very very simple
components and the first of which is

going to be a maple cream syrup that we
actually cook our pudding in and buy in

I actually mean under and by putting
actually mean cake don't worry it will

all make sense so what we're gonna do is
add equal parts of maple syrup and heavy

cream to this saucepan and we will
carefully bring this up to a boil on

medium high and I say carefully because
you really do need to watch what you're

doing here alright this mixture is going
to go from barely simmering to totally

exploding in like three seconds
alright so consider yourselves warned

and let me show you here what that's
going to look like

alright gentle bubble gentle bubble and
then final an explosion right so keep

your hands and face out of the way but
the good news is we don't have to go any

see that start to boil what we'll do is

turn off our heat and give it a stir and
that's it we'll simply reserve that

until needed and then once that's set we
can move on to our second component

which is basically a very very simple
cake mix and that's going to start with

some room temperature unsalted butter
into which we're gonna cream some white

sugar and my preferred tool of choice
here is a stiff rubber spatula although

if you want feel free to use an electric
mixer which is going to be a little

faster and easier but it's not really
gonna come out any better

Plus mixing this up is as close to some
of this are going to get to exercise

this week so I'm going to be doing this
all by hand and what we want to do is

keep smearing that butter and sugar
together until we have a beautiful nice

light smooth mixture that hopefully ends
up looking a little something like this

and then once that's been accomplished
we'll go ahead and switch to a whisk and

we'll proceed to add the rest of our wet
ingredients

which includes a little touch a real
appear of an L extract as well as two

eggs which to make things a little
easier will be whisking in one at a time

and the reason we usually don't do both
at the same time is because eggs are

mostly water and we're mixing that into
a mixture of this mostly butter if we

put both eggs in here and started
whisking the mixture can kind of

separate and it may actually end up
taking longer than if you just mixed in

one at a time so we will go ahead and
whisk that first day again until we feel

like it's been incorporated at which
point we'll add the second and final egg

and by the way even if you do add them
one at a time especially if you're

mixing by hand
it still can look like it's separating a

little bit but don't let that throw you
off that's not going to matter after we

add our dry ingredients
as you're gonna see it will start by

sprinkling over a spoon of baking powder
followed by a little bit of salt and

then last but not least we will add our
flour and that's it we'll simply switch

back to our spatula and give this a mix
until it's all combined and yes

technically we are supposed to mix our
salt and baking powder into the flour

first but don't worry in this kind of a
batter it really doesn't matter alright

this is what we call in the business a
rustic recipe which means we don't have

to use all the proper techniques and it
still comes out good but anyway we're

gonna go ahead and mix this up with our

done is go ahead and transfer it into
some kind of butter dish and we'll go

ahead and transfer that in and then
maybe switch to a butter knife so we can

to use the right size and shape dish

here is just a deep pie dish which is
you're about to see is a little too

small for this recipe see what we need
to do after this is transferred in and

all smoothed out is we have to ladle
over our hot maple cream mixture

if theoretically we're supposed to add
all of it to the top and then what

happens as this cooks our cake mixture
kind of rises up through that cerb and

once this comes out of the oven what
we'll have is cake on the top and a

beautiful nice runny layer of sauce

this dish is too small I don't have
enough room to ladle it all in alright

because you're gonna want to stop at
least about a half inch from the top

otherwise this is gonna boil
everywhere so I ladle in as much as I

could and as you can see here I had two

relax is still gonna work and yes I
could have put this in a bigger dish but

my next size up would have made it too

you will see what happens but in the
meantime let's go ahead and carefully

transfer this into the center of a
425-degree oven for about 30 minutes or

so or until it looks like this check it
out as predicted as that batter cook

that came up through that syrup and rose

whole bunch of it and to test if it's
done if you're not quite sure you can

use a toothpick and it should come out

raw batter put it back in and unlike
almost every other baked dessert we've

ever done we do not have to let this

ahead and let this sit for about 10
minutes before taking a spoon and

serving this up and had I done this in a

but rather than just garnish our plates
with a little bit of that once we serve

up to make it seem legit alright
remember with food it doesn't have to be

because as you can imagine this stuff is

were and that's it my take on pudding

which for some reason we're calling it

something called poor man's pudding
requires such expensive ingredients like

maple syrup and cream
well that's because apparently during

the Depression these farmers didn't have
any money but they did have plenty of

cows and maple trees so unlike today
these ingredients were not expensive so

don't let that very ironic name throw
you off this really is a gorgeous easy

to make and very versatile dessert
